results.abstract: Astronauts aboard space shuttle Atlantis say goodbye to their comrades on Mir space station and seal hatches for trip home (S)

headline.main: National News Briefs; Shuttle Crew Prepares To Leave Russian Station

results.snippet: After dropping off a new computer and a new American crewman, the astronauts aboard the space shuttle Atlantis hugged their comrades on the Mir space station goodbye today and sealed the hatches for the trip home.    ''Be careful down there on...
results.lead_paragraph: After dropping off a new computer and a new American crewman, the astronauts aboard the space shuttle Atlantis hugged their comrades on the Mir space station goodbye today and sealed the hatches for the trip home. ''Be careful down there on Earth,'' Dr. David A. Wolf, an astronaut who will spend the next four months aboard Mir, told his departing shuttle colleagues and everyone listening back on the planet.

results.abstract: Space shuttle Atlantis pulls away from Russian space station Mir for flight home, leaving behind Dr David A Wolf, American physician, as well as new computer that should make his four-and-a-half-month stay safer and more productive; Wolf replaces Dr C Michael Foale, who heads home after often stressful four and half months aboard Mir (M)

headline.main: Shuttle Leaves Russia Outpost For a Return Sunday Night

results.snippet: The space shuttle Atlantis pulled away from the Russian space station Mir today for the flight home, leaving behind an American physician as well as a new computer that should make his four-and-a-half month stay safer and more productive.    The...
results.lead_paragraph: The space shuttle Atlantis pulled away from the Russian space station Mir today for the flight home, leaving behind an American physician as well as a new computer that should make his four-and-a-half month stay safer and more productive. The physician, Dr. David A. Wolf, watched quietly as Atlantis backed away in darkness 250 miles above Russia. Dr. Wolf replaced Dr. C. Michael Foale, who headed home after an often stressful four and a half months aboard the run-down Russian space station.

results.abstract: Space shuttle Atlantis returns to Cape Canaveral, bringing home astronaut Michael Foale after tumultuous four-and-one-half months aboard Russian space station Mir; photo; thick clouds had kept shuttle, and Foale, in orbit for extra day; British-born astrophysicist is greeted by wife and two young children (S)

headline.main: Shuttle, a Day Late, Returns With U.S. Astronaut From Mir

results.snippet: The space shuttle Atlantis returned to Earth on Monday, bringing home the American astronaut Dr. Michael Foale after a tumultuous four and one half months aboard the Mir space station.    The Atlantis swooped through a hazy sky and landed at the...
results.lead_paragraph: The space shuttle Atlantis returned to Earth on Monday, bringing home the American astronaut Dr. Michael Foale after a tumultuous four and one half months aboard the Mir space station. The Atlantis swooped through a hazy sky and landed at the Kennedy Space Center just before 6 P.M., one day late.

results.abstract: Lawrence Van Gelder reviews Disney film Rocketman, directed by Stuart Gillard; photo (S)

headline.main: A Nerd Who Gets a Life (And a Love) in Space

results.snippet: To imagine the 1995 film ''Apollo 13'' as a tale told by idiots is to plumb the shallows of the new release called ''Rocketman.''    Flying under the Walt Disney Pictures banner, ''Rocketman'' is a dimwitted juvenile comedy built around the antics of...
results.lead_paragraph: To imagine the 1995 film ''Apollo 13'' as a tale told by idiots is to plumb the shallows of the new release called ''Rocketman.'' Flying under the Walt Disney Pictures banner, ''Rocketman'' is a dimwitted juvenile comedy built around the antics of Harland Williams as a computer nerd pressed into service as an astronaut on a $40 billion NASA mission to put the first humans on Mars.

results.snippet: Bill Gregory once gazed at Earth through a window in space. Gary Johnson was running races in New Mexico long before he began running for office. Tim Jacobs makes a living guarding the President's life, and Alexandra Paul spent years roaming a...
results.lead_paragraph: Bill Gregory once gazed at Earth through a window in space. Gary Johnson was running races in New Mexico long before he began running for office. Tim Jacobs makes a living guarding the President's life, and Alexandra Paul spent years roaming a California beach with David Hasselhoff. Gregory, the astronaut; Johnson, the Governor of New Mexico; Jacobs, a United States Secret Service agent, and Paul, an actress, have been altering the course of their lives in recent months to prepare for what is perhaps the toughest course in all of sports.

results.abstract: NASA says that astronaut Andrew Thomas, who is scheduled to replace David Wolf in January aboard Russian space station Mir, will be last American astronaut to live on Mir (S)

headline.main: National News Briefs; Seventh Astronaut to Be Last American on Mir

results.snippet: The astronaut Andrew Thomas, who is scheduled to replace David Wolf in January aboard the Russian space station Mir in January, will be the last American astronaut to live on Mir, NASA has said.    Mr. Thomas will be the seventh and last American to...
results.lead_paragraph: The astronaut Andrew Thomas, who is scheduled to replace David Wolf in January aboard the Russian space station Mir in January, will be the last American astronaut to live on Mir, NASA has said. Mr. Thomas will be the seventh and last American to complete a stay of several months on Mir, NASA said on Friday -- after Norman Thagard, Shannon Lucid, John Blaha, Jerry Linenger, Michael Foale and Mr. Wolf, who began his four-month stay in the Russian station on Oct. 2.

results.abstract: Danger of fire in space is now receiving serious attention, following crisis on Mir in February, when candle-type generator caught fire, resulting in four-foot flames, causing chunks of molten metal to fly through air, spattering bulkhead; sparks erupted, and smoke billowed through stations, clouding vision and making air unbreathable; fire lasted 14 minutes; now, scientists are studying fire's mysterious behavior in weightlessness and hunt for better ways to block and fight its dangers, and scientists are continuously surprised at how fire behaves in space (M)

headline.main: Mir Prompts New Effort to Quench Threat of Fire in Space

results.snippet: ONE day last February, an astronaut on the Russian space station Mir was preparing to make a batch of life-giving oxygen when the candle-type generator he was using caught fire. Almost instantly, flames were shooting out one to four feet, and chunks...
results.lead_paragraph: ONE day last February, an astronaut on the Russian space station Mir was preparing to make a batch of life-giving oxygen when the candle-type generator he was using caught fire. Almost instantly, flames were shooting out one to four feet, and chunks of molten metal were flying through the air, splattering a nearby bulkhead. Sparks erupted like fireworks, and smoke billowed through the station, clouding vision and making the air unbreathable. Dr. Jerry M. Linenger, an American astronaut on board, grabbed an emergency mask, but no oxygen came out. He seized another while struggling to free fire extinguishers that were still attached to bulkheads with the heavy bolts that had secured them for the launching.

results.abstract: Stephen Holden reviews documentary movie Mission to Mir, directed by Ivan Galin; photo (S)

headline.main: Cramped in the Vastness of Outer Space

results.snippet: If you have the tiniest inkling of claustrophobia, don't even think about attempting space travel, at least not the way it is done now, in its early pioneering phase. ''Mission to Mir,'' a visually sweeping 40-minute documentary, much of which was...
results.lead_paragraph: If you have the tiniest inkling of claustrophobia, don't even think about attempting space travel, at least not the way it is done now, in its early pioneering phase. ''Mission to Mir,'' a visually sweeping 40-minute documentary, much of which was shot inside the Russian Mir space station, doesn't talk much about the anxieties and discomforts of space travel, but its close-up pictures of astronauts crammed into tiny spaces certainly let you sense them. Filled with stunning images of rocket launchings along with optimistic talk about international cooperation after the cold war, ''Mission to Mir'' is a seductive advertisement for the United States space program, which has participated with Russia in sending astronauts from both countries to live on the Mir. The twangy-voiced American astronaut Shannon Lucid serves as a likable, down-to-earth poster girl. Unflappably calm and good-natured about her adventures, this salt-of-the-earth wife and mother from Oklahoma laughingly describes the most frustrating moment during her six-month stay in space as coming to the end of a science fiction book one of her children had given her and realizing she wouldn't be able to read the sequel, which explained the plot, until she returned to Earth.

results.abstract: Grace Glueck reviews exhibitions of works by folk artist William L Hawkins at Museum of American Folk Art and Ricco/Maresca Gallery; photo (S)
results.snippet: William L. Hawkins    Museum of American Folk Art  2 Lincoln Square  Manhattan  Through Nov. 2    Ricco/Maresca Gallery  529 West 20th Street  Chelsea  Through Nov. 8       There's no confusion about the name, birthplace and birth date of the folk...
results.lead_paragraph: William L. Hawkins Museum of American Folk Art 2 Lincoln Square Manhattan Through Nov. 2 Ricco/Maresca Gallery 529 West 20th Street Chelsea Through Nov. 8 There's no confusion about the name, birthplace and birth date of the folk artist William L. Hawkins (1895-1990). He emblazoned them somewhere on every picture he turned out: WILLIAM L. HAWKINS BORN JULY 27, 1895 KY.'' And his works in these two shows are loud, clear and colorful: from fanciful wild animals to personages, events, fancy buildings and religious tableaux. But by now, so barraged are we with the folksy cuteness of ''outsider'' art that much of Hawkins's work comes across as cliched.

results.abstract: Richard Garriot, creator of popular 18-year-old Dungeons and Dragons-style computer games, is poised to benefit from rise of Internet and rapid growth in popularity of multiplayer personal computer games; his 'Ultima Online' is one of first illustrated Internet games that thousands of people can play at once; he sold 40,000 units of Ultima Online, at $64.95 each, in first three weeks; early success of Ultima is being taken as sign in computer game industry that Internet is arriving as standard feature built in to all computer games; chart comparing Ultima Online with Quake, enormously popular action shooter game; photos; diagrams (M)

headline.main: The Ultimate Obsession; What Will People Pay to Enter His World?

results.snippet: Entering the three-story foyer of Richard Garriot's hilltop estate is a short trip into another dimension. The high walls are covered with crossbows and other menacing medieval weapons, overhead is an imposing astronomical observatory. At eye level,...
results.lead_paragraph: Entering the three-story foyer of Richard Garriot's hilltop estate is a short trip into another dimension. The high walls are covered with crossbows and other menacing medieval weapons, overhead is an imposing astronomical observatory. At eye level, there is a bullet hole in the staircase. But then, none of this is unexpected, for inside the insular computing gaming world Mr. Garriot, the creator of the popular 18-year-old Ultima series of Dungeons and Dragons-style computer games, has a reputation for building elaborate and compelling fantasy worlds. Now, with a new game on the market, he is poised to benefit from both the rise of the Internet and the rapid growth in popularity of multiplayer personal computer games. He is, in fact, quickly becoming the George Lucas of a business that is capturing an increasingly mainstream following.

results.abstract: Astronauts aboard Russian Mir space station clear away floating debris and connect several new cables during internal spacewalk in Specktr module, which was damaged by cargo ship in June (M)

headline.main: A Spacewalk Of Surprises Aboard Mir

results.snippet: Crewmen aboard the Mir space station cleared away floating space debris and connected several new cables today during an ''internal spacewalk'' that should increase the damaged Russian craft's power supply.    However, the two Russian astronauts,...
results.lead_paragraph: Crewmen aboard the Mir space station cleared away floating space debris and connected several new cables today during an ''internal spacewalk'' that should increase the damaged Russian craft's power supply. However, the two Russian astronauts, Anatoly Solovyov and Pavel Vinogradov, were unable to hook up one of the six new cables in their 6-hour, 38-minute mission.

results.abstract: Article by Burkhard Bilger on gray issues of science, such as genetic planning and euthanasia, that are main themes of films Gattaca and Critical Care; photo (L)

headline.main: In Living Color, the Gray Areas of Science

results.snippet: THE JOYS OF CHILDBIRTH, 21st-century style: a wailing baby is carried to a counter top and unceremoniously pricked. While the parents look on, a drop of blood is fed into a machine, and a nurse reads impassively from the printout: ''Neurological...
results.lead_paragraph: THE JOYS OF CHILDBIRTH, 21st-century style: a wailing baby is carried to a counter top and unceremoniously pricked. While the parents look on, a drop of blood is fed into a machine, and a nurse reads impassively from the printout: ''Neurological condition probability, 60 percent. Manic-depression probability, 42 percent. Attention-deficit disorder probability, 89 percent.'' Then, after a pause and a sideways glance at the father: ''Heart disorder probability, 99 percent. Early fatal potential. Life expectancy, 30.2 years.'' Dad is devastated. Only 30 years? On second thought, maybe he'll make the next boy his namesake. Like most scenes in ''Gattaca,'' the science-fiction film that opened on Friday, starring Ethan Hawke and Uma Thurman, this one evokes the perils of genetic testing. In another sense, however, it could be an allegory for the risky birth of the film itself. A comedy or action film is born every hour, but a drama focused on a serious scientific issue is a rare breed, one fraught with congenital handicaps. Prone to hype, inaccuracy and bloodlessness (call it a high heart-disorder probability), such issue-oriented films tend to sell their subjects short (see ''Outbreak'') or sag under their own good intentions (see ''Contact''). They are, in the futuristic lingo of ''Gattaca,'' ''faith babies.''

results.abstract: American astronaut Michael Foale says most of his stay aboard troubled Russian space station Mir was worthwhile and enjoyable, but that he briefly feared for his life when runaway cargo vessel struck station, news conference (M)

headline.main: For the American Astronaut, One Bad Moment Aboard Mir

results.snippet: The American astronaut Michael Foale said today that most of his stay aboard the troubled Russian space station Mir was worthwhile and enjoyable, but that for a brief moment he feared for his life when a runaway cargo vessel struck the orbiting...
results.lead_paragraph: The American astronaut Michael Foale said today that most of his stay aboard the troubled Russian space station Mir was worthwhile and enjoyable, but that for a brief moment he feared for his life when a runaway cargo vessel struck the orbiting outpost. Dr. Foale, in his first news conference since returning to Earth three weeks ago, said at the Johnson Space Center in Houston that the only time he feared for his life was ''for about one second'' on June 25 when a Progress cargo vessel conducting a docking test slammed into one of Mir's main modules.

results.snippet: INTERNATIONAL   A3-21    Summit Leads to Deals But No Progress on Rights  President Clinton and President Jiang Zemin of China engaged in a day of contentious talks during which several commercial agreements were announced and Mr. Jiang forcefully...
results.lead_paragraph: INTERNATIONAL A3-21 Summit Leads to Deals But No Progress on Rights President Clinton and President Jiang Zemin of China engaged in a day of contentious talks during which several commercial agreements were announced and Mr. Jiang forcefully defended what he called China's historic preference for order over personal freedom. A1
